articles.headline: Virginia Lieutenant Governor Faces Eroding Support From Democrats After New Accuser Speaks
articles.snippet: The new allegation follows one by a California professor, Vanessa Tyson, who says Mr. Fairfax sexually assaulted her in 2004.
articles.abstract: The new allegation follows one by a California professor, Vanessa Tyson, who says Mr. Fairfax sexually assaulted her in 2004.
articles.lead_paragraph: A second woman came forward Friday with claims that she had been sexually assaulted by Lt. Gov. Justin E. Fairfax of Virginia, intensifying the weeklong political crisis in the state and leading top fellow Democrats to call for Mr. Fairfax to resign.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Virginia’s Racist History Clashes With New South Image
articles.snippet: Revelations about past racist behavior by top Virginia politicians are testing the state’s reputation as a progressive-minded beacon that backed Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton.
articles.abstract: Revelations about past racist behavior by top Virginia politicians are testing the state’s reputation as a progressive-minded beacon that backed Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — L. Douglas Wilder, a grandson of slaves, became America’s first elected black governor 30 years ago, winning in Virginia in part by finessing the racist history of the state that is now roiling its politics once more.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: For Democrats Aiming Taxes at the Superrich, ‘the Moment Belongs to the Bold’
articles.snippet: Soak-the-rich plans that seemed politically far-fetched just months ago are getting a full-throttle response from voters.
articles.abstract: Soak-the-rich plans that seemed politically far-fetched just months ago are getting a full-throttle response from voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: The only thing more startling than the flurry of tax proposals Democrats have unveiled in recent weeks is the full-throttle response they’ve gotten from the public.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Maggie Astor

articles.headline: In Surprise Abortion Vote, John Roberts Avoids ‘Jolt to the Legal System’
articles.snippet: The chief justice, a student of legal rules governing precedent, balances guarding his court’s legitimacy against his generally conservative impulses.
articles.abstract: The chief justice, a student of legal rules governing precedent, balances guarding his court’s legitimacy against his generally conservative impulses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s confirmation hearings 14 years ago, the first dozen questions were about whether he would respect the Supreme Court’s abortion precedents. He was still answering those questions Thursday night.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Les Moonves, Fired by CBS, Sets Up Shop in Hollywood
articles.snippet: The ousted chief executive of CBS is occupying an office on Hollywood’s Sunset Strip that, per his exit agreement, is being paid for by the network.
articles.abstract: The ousted chief executive of CBS is occupying an office on Hollywood’s Sunset Strip that, per his exit agreement, is being paid for by the network.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just months after being fired by CBS, Leslie Moonves is running a new company.
articles.byline: By David Gelles, Rachel Abrams and Edmund Lee

articles.headline: Jeff Bezos’ Extortion Claim Said to Be Under Review by Prosecutors
articles.snippet: If American Media is found to have broken a law, it would be in violation of a deal struck with federal prosecutors in connection to hush money paid to protect Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: If American Media is found to have broken a law, it would be in violation of a deal struck with federal prosecutors in connection to hush money paid to protect Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon and the owner of The Washington Post, did not become the world’s richest man by refusing to do what it takes to win. And now that he finds himself in a mud fight with the supermarket tabloid that exposed his extramarital affair, he is showing off the same drive that helped him turn a simple idea — selling books on the internet — into an all-purpose, $780 billion powerhouse.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Karen Weise and William K. Rashbaum

articles.headline: You Call That Meat? Not So Fast, Cattle Ranchers Say
articles.snippet: With new vegetarian and lab-produced burgers coming to stores, several states are looking to bar newcomers from using the word meat on their labels.
articles.abstract: With new vegetarian and lab-produced burgers coming to stores, several states are looking to bar newcomers from using the word meat on their labels.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The cattle ranchers and farm bureaus of America are not going to give up their hold on the word meat without a fight.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Justin Fairfax Puts Virginia Democrats in Bind on Impeachment
articles.snippet: If Democrats do not oust Mr. Fairfax, who faces sexual assault allegations, they could anger female voters. But if they push him out, they could deeply trouble African-Americans.
articles.abstract: If Democrats do not oust Mr. Fairfax, who faces sexual assault allegations, they could anger female voters. But if they push him out, they could deeply trouble African-Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Justin E. Fairfax’s refusal to resign as lieutenant governor of Virginia in the face of two allegations of sexual assault has presented Democrats with an excruciating choice: whether to impeach an African-American leader at a moment when the state’s other two top leaders, both white, are resisting calls to quit after admitting to racist conduct.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Alan Blinder and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Sanders and O’Rourke Are Way Ahead in Race for Small-Dollar Donors
articles.snippet: A Times analysis shows that in the contest for small donors, there is a wide gap between the haves, led by Bernie Sanders, and have-nots like Cory Booker.
articles.abstract: A Times analysis shows that in the contest for small donors, there is a wide gap between the haves, led by Bernie Sanders, and have-nots like Cory Booker.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders would begin a 2020 presidential bid with 2.1 million online donors, a massive lead among low-dollar contributors that is roughly equivalent to the donor base of all the other Democratic hopefuls combined.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Lisa Lerer and Rachel Shorey

articles.headline: Nun’s Rape Case Against Bishop Shakes a Catholic Bastion in India
articles.snippet: After church officials urged her to stay silent for more than a year, a nun who says the bishop raped her 13 times finally sees her case move toward trial.
articles.abstract: After church officials urged her to stay silent for more than a year, a nun who says the bishop raped her 13 times finally sees her case move toward trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOCHI, India — When Bishop Franco Mulakkal agreed to personally celebrate the First Communion for Darly’s son, a rare honor in their Catholic Church in India, the family was overcome with pride.
articles.byline: By Maria Abi-Habib and Suhasini Raj

articles.headline: ‘Dangerous Territory’ for Democrats as Republicans Seize Venezuela Moment in Miami
articles.snippet: If President Trump helps force President Nicolás Maduro out of office, Democrats fear it could transform Venezuelan Americans into loyal Republicans.
articles.abstract: If President Trump helps force President Nicolás Maduro out of office, Democrats fear it could transform Venezuelan Americans into loyal Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For 60 years, the lifeblood of Miami’s idiosyncratic politics has been Cuba, the communist government’s countless sins denounced in street protests, dissected on the spirited Spanish-language airwaves and condemned at campaign rallies under the unifying cry of “Viva Cuba Libre!”
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: A Princess Vanishes. A Video Offers Alarming Clues.
articles.snippet: The adult daughter of Dubai’s ruler tried to escape a life of stultifying restrictions. She was captured at sea, forcibly taken back, and has not been heard from since.
articles.abstract: The adult daughter of Dubai’s ruler tried to escape a life of stultifying restrictions. She was captured at sea, forcibly taken back, and has not been heard from since.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The princess known as Sheikha Latifa had not left Dubai, the glittering emirate ruled by her father, in 18 years. Her requests to travel and study elsewhere had been denied. Her passport had been taken away. Her friends’ apartments were forbidden to her, her palace off-limits to them.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee

articles.headline: Talks Over Border Security Break Down, Imperiling Effort to Prevent Shutdown
articles.snippet: Lawmakers and aides familiar with the negotiations said the number of beds for housing detained migrants already in the country was the main sticking point.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers and aides familiar with the negotiations said the number of beds for housing detained migrants already in the country was the main sticking point.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional efforts to reach a border security deal ahead of another government shutdown broke down on Sunday over Democratic demands to limit the detention of undocumented immigrants, as President Trump moved more troops to the border and prepared to rally supporters in Texas on Monday.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane, Maggie Haberman and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Cryptocurrency Was Their Way Out of South Korea’s Lowest Rungs. They’re Still Trying.
articles.snippet: A generation of the young with dead-end social and economic prospects, calling themselves “dirt spoons,” aimed to strike it rich. They’ve ended up with big losses.
articles.abstract: A generation of the young with dead-end social and economic prospects, calling themselves “dirt spoons,” aimed to strike it rich. They’ve ended up with big losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Ki-won is keeping a secret from his parents.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Su-Hyun Lee

articles.headline: The Next Wave of ‘Unicorn’ Start-Ups
articles.snippet: Uber and Airbnb were part of an early generation of tech start-ups that quickly reached $1 billion in value. The up-and-coming generation is looking very different.
articles.abstract: Uber and Airbnb were part of an early generation of tech start-ups that quickly reached $1 billion in value. The up-and-coming generation is looking very different.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Technology start-ups worth $1 billion, once as rare as unicorns, are now plentiful enough and old enough that there’s a new generation behind them — one that looks very different.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Flip-Flop by Fed Scrambles Outlook for World Markets
articles.snippet: The central bank’s new friendly tone cascaded through the financial world in ways large and small. A look at the consequences.
articles.abstract: The central bank’s new friendly tone cascaded through the financial world in ways large and small. A look at the consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once again, the Federal Reserve has upended markets.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips

articles.headline: In Closed Hearing, a Clue About ‘the Heart’ of Mueller’s Russia Inquiry
articles.snippet: Prosecutors for the special counsel suggested plans discussed by Trump associates to address Russia’s conflict with Ukraine and the resulting sanctions remained at the center of the investigation.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors for the special counsel suggested plans discussed by Trump associates to address Russia’s conflict with Ukraine and the resulting sanctions remained at the center of the investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Of the few hints to emerge from the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, about evidence of possible collusion between President Trump’s campaign and Russia, one of the most tantalizing surfaced almost in passing in a Washington courtroom last week.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Kenneth P. Vogel and Scott Shane

articles.headline: For Virginia Governor Grappling With Race, a Childhood Trying to See Beyond It
articles.snippet: Ralph Northam’s early life, growing up on Virginia’s rural Eastern Shore, provides clues about how his perspectives on race were shaped.
articles.abstract: Ralph Northam’s early life, growing up on Virginia’s rural Eastern Shore, provides clues about how his perspectives on race were shaped.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONANCOCK, Va. — When the United States Supreme Court ordered school districts in 1968 to dismantle their segregated classrooms, Wescott and Nancy Northam had a choice to make.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Elizabeth Williamson

articles.headline: ‘Progressive Prosecutor’: Can Kamala Harris Square the Circle?
articles.snippet: Ms. Harris seemed to try to be all things to all people as a district attorney and state attorney general. Now, as she runs for president, her record faces a chorus of critics, especially on the left.
articles.abstract: Ms. Harris seemed to try to be all things to all people as a district attorney and state attorney general. Now, as she runs for president, her record faces a chorus of critics, especially on the left.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Kamala Harris was three months into her tenure as San Francisco district attorney in 2004 when a gang member killed a police officer with a hail of bullets from an AK-47. Her announcement within three days of the murder that she would not seek the death penalty set off protests from her fellow Democrats as well as from the police.
articles.byline: By Kate Zernike

articles.headline: Ilhan Omar Apologizes for Statements Condemned as Anti-Semitic
articles.snippet: The implication by Ms. Omar, a freshman representative from Minnesota, that Jewish money is driving pro-Israel sentiments drew fierce rebukes, including from fellow Democrats.
articles.abstract: The implication by Ms. Omar, a freshman representative from Minnesota, that Jewish money is driving pro-Israel sentiments drew fierce rebukes, including from fellow Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Ilhan Omar, who has been battling charges of anti-Semitism for weeks, apologized on Monday for insinuating that American support for Israel is fueled by money from a pro-Israel lobbying group — a comment that drew swift and unqualified condemnation from fellow Democrats, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
